title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.

title: Place of birth
text: This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.

title: Place of birth
text: As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.

title: Place of birth
text: If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.

title: Place of birth
text: For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.

title: Place of birth
text: This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.

title: Place of birth
text: Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.

title: Place of birth
text: In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".

title: Place of birth
text: Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").

title: Place of birth
text: There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).

title: Place of birth
text: Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".

title: Place of birth
text: It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".

title: Place of birth
text: For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: Caterina Sforza (1463 – 28 May 1509) was an Italian noblewoman along with the Countess of Forlì and Lady of Imola, firstly with her husband Girolamo Riario, and after his death as a regent of her son Ottaviano.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: Caterina was the illegitimate daughter of Galeazzo Maria Sforza, Duke of Milan and Lucrezia, the wife of the courtier Gian Piero Landriani, a close friend of the Duke.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: She was raised in the refined Milanese court.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: The descendant of a dynasty of noted condottieri, from an early age, Caterina distinguished herself through her bold and impetuous actions taken to safeguard her possessions from possible usurpers and to defend her dominions from attack, when they were involved in political intrigues.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: In her private life Caterina was devoted to various activities, including experiments in alchemy and a love of hunting and dancing.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: She had many children, but

title: Caterina Sforza
text: only the youngest, Captain Giovanni dalle Bande Nere, inherited his mother's forceful, militant personality.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: Caterina's resistance to Cesare Borgia meant she had to face his fury and imprisonment.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: Once she gained her freedom in Rome, she led a quiet life in Florence.

title: Caterina Sforza
text: In the final years of her life, she confided to a monk: "Se io potessi scrivere tutto, farei stupire

title: Caterina Sforza
text: il mondoIf

title: Caterina Sforza

title: Swedenhielms
text: Swedenhielms is a 1935 Swedish comedy-drama film directed by Gustaf Molander.

title: Gustaf Molander
text: Gustaf Harald August Molander (18 November 1888 – 19 June 1973) was a Swedish actor and film director.

title: Gustaf Molander
text: His parents were director Harald Molander, Sr.

title: Gustaf Molander
text: (1858–1900) and singer and actress Lydia Molander, "née" Wessler, and his brother was director Olof Molander (1892–1966).

title: Gustaf Molander
text: He was the father of director and producer Harald Molander from his first marriage to actress Karin Molander and father to actor Jan Molander from his second marriage to Elsa Fahlberg (1892-1977).

title: Gustaf Molander
text: Gustaf Molander was born in Helsingfors (now Helsinki) in the Grand Duchy of Finland (in the Russian Empire), where his father was working at the Swedish Theatre.

title: Gustaf Molander
text: He studied in the school of the Royal Dramatic Theatre in Stockholm 1907–1909, acted at the Swedish theatre in Helsingfors 1909–1913, and then at the Royal Dramatic Theatre from 1913–1926.

title: Gustaf Molander
text: The last years there he headed the school; his students included Greta Garbo.

title: Gustaf Molander
text: Molander wrote several screenplays for Victor Sjöström and Mauritz Stiller, and was helped by the latter to get employment as a director for Svensk Filmindustri, where he worked 1923–1956.

title: Gustaf Molander
text: All in all, he directed sixty-two films.

title: Gustaf Molander
text: He often worked with Gösta Ekman, and his films include "Intermezzo" (1936), which became Ingrid Bergman's breakthrough and paved her way to America, where she starred in the 1939 Hollywood remake of the film.

title: Jan Baptist van Rensselaer
text: Jan Baptist van Rensselaer (Amsterdam 18 March 1629–Amsterdam, 24 October 1678) was the second son of Kiliaen van Rensselaer, the first Patroon of the Manor of Rensselaerswyck.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: Stephen Van Rensselaer III( November 1, 1764 January 26, 1839) was a New York landowner, businessman, militia officer, and politician.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: A graduate of Harvard University, at age 21, Van Rensselaer took control of Rensselaerswyck, his family's manor.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: He developed the land by encouraging tenants to settle it, and granting them perpetual leases at moderate rates, which enabled the tenants to use more of their capital to make their farms and businesses productive.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: Active in politics as a Federalist, Van Rensselaer served in the New York State Assembly and New York State Senate, and as Lieutenant Governor of New York.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: After the demise of the Federalist Party, Van Rensselaer was a John Quincy Adams supporter, and served in the United States House of Representatives for one partial term and three full ones.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: Van Rensselaer was a supporter of higher education; he served on the board of trustees for several schools and colleges, and was the founder of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: He was also a civic activist and philanthropist, and was a founder of Albany's public library and the city's Institute of History& Arts.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: Long active in the militia, Van Rensselaer attained the rank of major general; he commanded troops on the New York- Canada border during the War of 1812, but resigned his commission after defeat at the Battle of Queenston Heights.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: After Van Rensselaer's 1839 death, efforts by his sons to collect past due lease payments led to the Anti-Rent War, and the break up and sale of the manor.

title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
text: As the heir to and then owner of one of the largest estates in New York, Van Rensselaer's holdings made him the tenth richest American of all time, based on the ratio of his fortune to contemporary GDP.

title: Jeremias Van Rensselaer (sixth patroon)
text: Jeremias van Rensselaer( March 18, 1705 – 1745) was the eldest son of Kiliaen van Rensselaer and Maria van Cortlandt.

title: Jan Baptist van Fornenburgh
text: Jan Baptist van Fornenburgh( 1585 in Antwerp – 1650 in The Hague), was a Dutch Golden Age flower painter.

title: Johannes Van Rensselaer
text: Johannes Van Rensselaer( January 3, 1708 – February 21, 1783) was a member of the prominent colonial Van Rensselaer family.

title: Jan Baptist van der Hulst
text: Jan Baptist van der Hulst( 2 March 1790 in Leuven- 16 May 1862 in Brussels) was a Flemish painter and lithographer.

title: Jan Baptist van der Hulst
text: He painted numerous members of the royal family of the Netherlands, and was known for his work in history painting as well.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (1586 – buried 7 October 1643) was a Dutch diamond and pearl merchant from Amsterdam who was one of the founders and directors of the Dutch West India Company, being instrumental in the establishment of New Netherland.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: He was one of the first patroons, but the only one to become successful.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: He founded the Manor of Rensselaerswyck in what is now mainly New York's Capital District.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: His estate remained throughout the Dutch and British colonial era and the American Revolution as a legal entity until the 1840s.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: Eventually, that came to an end during the Anti-Rent War.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: Van Rensselaer was the son of Hendrick Kiliaensz van Rensselaer, a soldier from Nijkerk in the "States army of the duke of Upper Saxony", and Maria Pafraet, descendant of a well-known printers' dynasty.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: To keep from risking his life in the army like his father, he apprenticed under his uncle, a successful Amsterdam jeweler.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: He too became a successful jeweler and was one of the first subscribers to the Dutch West India Company upon its conception.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: The concept of patroonships may have been Kiliaen van Rensselaer's; he was likely the leading proponent of the Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions, the document that established the patroon system.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: His patroonship became the most successful to exist, making full use of his business tactics and advantages, such as his connection to the Director of New Netherland, his confidantes at the West India Company, and his extended family members who were eager to emigrate to a better place to farm.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: Van Rensselaer married twice and had at least eleven children.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: When he died sometime after 1642, two succeeded him as patroons of Rensselaerswyck.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: Van Rensselaer had a marked effect on the history of the United States.

title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
text: The American Van Rensselaers all descend from Kiliaen's son Jeremias and the subsequent Van Rensselaer family is noted for being a very powerful and wealthy influence in the history of New York and the Northeastern United States, producing multiple State Legislators, Congressmen, and two Lieutenant Governors in New York.

title: Mariana Griswold Van Rensselaer
text: Mariana Alley Griswold Van Rensselaer( February 21, 1851 – January 20, 1934), usually known as Mrs. Schuyler Van Rensselaer or M. G. Van Rensselaer, was an American author focusing on architectural criticism.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: Round table is a form of academic discussion.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: Participants agree on a specific topic to discuss and debate.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: Each person is given equal right to participate, as illustrated by the idea of a circular layout referred to in the term round table.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: Round- table discussions, together with houses of hospitality and agronomic universities, is one of the key elements of the Catholic Worker Movement, as formulated by Peter Maurin, one of the co-founders of the movement.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: Round table discussions are also a common feature of political talk shows.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: Talk shows such as" Washington Week" and" Meet the Press" have roundtables of reporters or pundits.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: Most of these are done around a table in a studio, but occasionally they report in split- screen from remote locations.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: Some sports shows, such as ESPN's" Around the Horn", employ the round table format.

title: Round table (discussion)
text: The round table method is still highly used to this day.

title: Kids of the Round Table
text: Kids of the Round Table is a 1995 Canadian/ American fantasy film written and directed by Robert Tinnell.

title: Kids of the Round Table
text: Malcolm McDowell, Michael Ironside and newcomer Johnny Morina star in a modern- day adventure filled with medieval magic.

title: Round table (furniture)
text: A round table is a table which has no" head" and no" sides", and therefore no one person sitting at it is given a privileged position and all are treated as equals.

title: Round table (furniture)
text: The idea stems from the Arthurian legend about the Knights of the Round Table in Camelot.

title: Round table (furniture)
text: Today, round tables are often used at conferences involving many parties.

title: Round table (furniture)
text: The most famous modern round table was the one used for talks between the Communist government and Solidarity in Poland in 1989; see: Polish Round Table Agreement.

title: Round table (furniture)
text: Hence, the term" round table" is also used figuratively to refer to a peaceful way of achieving a compromise solution.

title: East German Round Table
text: Round table primarily refers to the Central Round Table(" Zentraler Runder Tisch"), a series of meetings during the Peaceful Revolution in East Germany in late- 1989 and early- 1990.

title: East German Round Table
text: The Round table first convened in East Berlin on 7 December 1989, the day after Egon Krenz had resigned as the head of the Socialist Unity Party( SED) government.

title: East German Round Table
text: This Round Table, modeled after the Polish Round Table convened in April 1989, was initiated by the group Democracy Now.

title: East German Round Table
text: " Round table" was to be understood in a methaphoric sense, meaning that the participants were on a par with each other.

title: East German Round Table
text: Physically, the table was rectangular( unlike the Polish model which was literally round).

title: East German Round Table
text: It was set up as a forum in which members of East German government- aligned organizations( such as the so- called bloc parties, trade unions, etc.) came together with representatives of the new citizens ’ movements( such as Democracy Now, Democratic Awakening, and New Forum) to discuss and advance reforms in the German Democratic Republic( East Germany), advising the executive until free elections could be held.

title: East German Round Table
text: There were 39 representatives at the Central Round Table, 33 of whom were entitled to vote.

title: East German Round Table
text: Seventeen of them represented new oppositional groups and political parties, and sixteen were from political parties and organizations that had been part of the communist- dominated East German government.

title: East German Round Table
text: Three, representing women, consumers and environmentalists, had observer status.

title: East German Round Table
text: The final three members were the moderators, all clergymen, from the Protestant, Catholic and Methodist churches, who did not have a vote.

title: East German Round Table
text: At first most participants hoped to reform the East German government and thus retain the country ’s independence, but as popular opinion moved towards rapid unification with West Germany, these hopes were dashed.

title: East German Round Table
text: The Round Table's first three meetings, held on 7, 18 and 22 December 1989, took place in the Protestant church's Bonhoeffer House near Friedrichstraße in Berlin- Mitte.

title: East German Round Table
text: Because popular interest created a need for more space, from the fourth meeting on 27 December to the sixteenth and final meeting on 12 March 1990, the Round Table met in the conference building of the SED- dominated Council of Ministers in Ossietzky St. near Schönhausen Palace in Berlin- Pankow.

title: East German Round Table
text: During the first meeting the Round Table decided to dissolve the" Office for National Security"( the organization that succeeded the Stasi), to hold free elections for the East German Parliament(" Volkskammer") on 6 May 1990( in January the election was preponed to 18 March 1990), and to draft a new constitution, a project that was completed by a subcommittee and presented on 4 April 1990, but never discussed by the newly elected" Volkskammer".

title: East German Round Table
text: Modeled after this Central Round Table, many local round tables were set up in cities and towns across East Germany.

title: East German Round Table
text: In general they continued to exist until the May 6, 1990 local elections constituted new local governments.

title: Isipum of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Ipum of Geumgwan Gaya( died 407)( r. 346–407) was the fifth ruler of Geumgwan Gaya, a Gaya state of ancient Korea.

title: Isipum of Geumgwan Gaya
text: He was the son of King Geojilmi and Queen Aji.

title: Isipum of Geumgwan Gaya
text: He married Queen Jeongsin, and she gave birth to his heir, Jwaji.

title: Queen Mojong
text: Queen Mojong was a wife of Geodeung of Geumgwan Gaya, the second king of Gaya confederacy.

title: Queen Mojong
text: She gave birth of the third king, Mapum of Geumgwan Gaya.

title: Queen Mojong
text: She was a daughter of Sin Po who was attendant of Heo Hwang- ok for her marriage from India.

title: Queen Mojong
text: In" Hwarang Segi", she was recorded as Sin Po ’s daughter, but in" Samgungnyusa", she was recorded as Sin Po ’s wife.

title: Geodeung of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Geodeung of Gaya, also called Geodeung Wang, was the king of Gaya, a confederacy of chiefdoms that existed in the Nakdong River valley of Korea during the Three Kingdoms era, from 199 to 259.

title: Geodeung of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Legend holds that he was the son of King Suro of Gaya and Suro's queen, Heo Hwang-ok.

title: Geodeung of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Legend says also they had in total ten sons.

title: Geodeung of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Geodeung Wang was married with Queen Mojong, who was the daughter of Sin Po Ch'onpukyong and Mojong.

title: Geodeung of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Sin Po was a courtier in Heo Hwang-ok's entourage.

title: Sin Po
text: Sin Po was a minister who served the kings in Gaya confederacy.

title: Sin Po
text: Queen Mojong who was the second wife of Geodeung of Geumgwan Gaya was his daughter.

title: Sin Po
text: He served as government officer of Gaya confederacy.

title: Sin Po
text: In 48, when Heo Hwang- ok came over from India to Gaya confederacy, he also came from India as an attendant of Heo Hwang- ok who married into Gaya confederacy.

title: Queen Hogu
text: Queen Hogu was the third wife of Mapum of Geumgwan Gaya.

title: Queen Hogu
text: She bore the fourth ruler of the Gaya confederacy, Geojilmi of Geumgwan Gaya.

title: Queen Hogu
text: She was the granddaughter of Cho Kuang, who was an attendant of Heo Hwang- ok for her marriage from India.

title: Gyeomji of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Gyeomji of Geumgwan Gaya( r. 492–521) was the ninth ruler of Geumgwan Gaya, a Gaya state of ancient Korea.

title: Gyeomji of Geumgwan Gaya
text: He was the son of King Jilji and Queen Bangwon.

title: Gyeomji of Geumgwan Gaya
text: He married Queen Suk, who was the daughter of the general(" gakgan") Chulchung.

title: Gyeomji of Geumgwan Gaya
text: She gave birth to Guhyeong, who would be the kingdom's final ruler.

title: Mapum of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Mapum of Geumgwan Gaya( died 291, r. 259–291) was king of Geumgwan Gaya, a member state of the Gaya confederacy.

title: Mapum of Geumgwan Gaya
text: He was preceded by his father, King Geodeung and succeeded by his son King Geojilmi.

title: Mapum of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Like the other members of the Geumgwan royal line, his surname was Kim.

title: Mapum of Geumgwan Gaya
text: His mother was Queen Mojong.

title: Mapum of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Mapum married Queen Hogu, who was the granddaughter of the high official Jo Gwang.

title: Chwihui of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Chwihui of Geumgwan Gaya( died 451)( r. 421–451) was the seventh ruler of Geumgwan Gaya, a Gaya state of ancient Korea.

title: Chwihui of Geumgwan Gaya
text: He was the son of King Jwaji and Queen Boksu.

title: Chwihui of Geumgwan Gaya
text: He married Indeok, daughter of the general(" gakgan")

title: Chwihui of Geumgwan Gaya
text: Jinsa.

title: Geojilmi of Geumgwan Gaya

title: Geojilmi of Geumgwan Gaya
text: He was the son of King Mapum and Queen Hogu.

title: Geojilmi of Geumgwan Gaya
text: King Geojilmi married Queen Aji, who was the granddaughter of a high official(" agan") named Agung.

title: Geojilmi of Geumgwan Gaya
text: She gave birth to his heir, Ipum.

title: Heo Hwang-ok
text: Heo Hwang-ok is a legendary queen mentioned in "Samguk Yusa", a 13th-century Korean chronicle.

title: Heo Hwang-ok
text: According to "Samguk Yusa" she became the wife of King Suro of Geumgwan Gaya at the age of 16, after having arrived by boat from a distant kingdom, making her the first queen of Geumgwan Gaya.

title: Heo Hwang-ok
text: According to some Korean historians there are more than six million present day Koreans, of which the majority are from Gimhae Kim clan with surnames Heo and 이

title: Heo Hwang-ok
text: (Lee/Yi)

title: Heo Hwang-ok
text: that trace their lineage to the legendary queen.

title: Heo Hwang-ok
text: Her native kingdom is believed to be located in India by some; there is, however, no mention of her in any pre-modern Indian sources.

title: Heo Hwang-ok
text: There is a tomb in Gimhae, Korea, that is believed by some to be hers, and a memorial in Ayodhya in India.

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: Peter Matthiessen (May 22, 1927 – April 5, 2014) was an American novelist, naturalist, wilderness writer, zen teacher and CIA officer.

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: A co-founder of the literary magazine "The Paris Review", he was the only writer to have won the National Book Award in both fiction and nonfiction.

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: He was also a prominent environmental activist.

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: Matthiessen's nonfiction featured nature and travel, notably "The Snow Leopard" (1978) and American Indian issues and history, such as a detailed and controversial study of the Leonard Peltier case, "

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: In the Spirit of Crazy Horse" (1983).

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: His fiction was adapted for film: the early story "Travelin' Man" was made into "The Young One" (1960) by Luis Buñuel and the novel "At Play in the Fields of the Lord" (1965) into the 1991 film of the same name.

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: In 2008, at age 81, Matthiessen received the National Book Award for Fiction for "Shadow Country", a one-volume, 890-page revision of his three novels set in frontier Florida that had been published in the 1990s.

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: According to critic Michael Dirda, "No one writes more lyrically  about animals or describes more movingly the spiritual experience of mountaintops, savannas, and the sea."

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: Matthiessen was treated for acute leukemia for more than a year.

title: Peter Matthiessen
text: He died on April 5, 2014, three days before publication of his final book, the novel "In Paradise" on April 8.

title: Joseph Duval

title: Joseph Duval

title: Charles Martel
text: Charles Martel (688 – 22 October 741) was a Frankish statesman and military leader who, as Duke and Prince of the Franks and Mayor of the Palace, was the "de facto" ruler of Francia from 718 until his death.

title: Charles Martel
text: He was a son of the Frankish statesman Pepin of Herstal and Pepin's mistress, a noblewoman named Alpaida.

title: Charles Martel
text: Charles successfully asserted his claims to power as successor to his father as the power behind the throne in Frankish politics.

title: Charles Martel
text: Continuing and building on his father's work, he restored centralized government in Francia and began the series of military campaigns that re-established the Franks as the undisputed masters of all Gaul.

title: Charles Martel
text: According to a near-contemporary source, the "Liber Historiae Francorum", Charles was "a warrior who was uncommonly effective in battle".

title: Charles Martel
text: Much attention has been paid to his success in defeating an Arab invasion in Aquitaine at the Battle of Tours.

title: Charles Martel
text: Alongside his military endeavours, Charles has been traditionally credited with a seminal role in the development of the Frankish system of feudalism.

title: Charles Martel
text: At the end of his reign, Charles divided Francia between his sons, Carloman and Pepin.

title: Charles Martel
text: The latter became the first king of the Carolingian dynasty.

title: Charles Martel
text: Charles' grandson, Charlemagne, extended the Frankish realms, and became the first emperor in the West since the fall of Rome.

title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
text: The Thirty Nine Steps is a British 1978 thriller film directed by Don Sharp, with screenplay by British playwright Michael Robson, based on the novel" The Thirty- Nine Steps" by John Buchan.

title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
text: It was the third film version of the 1915 novel.

title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
text: This version of Buchan's tale starred Robert Powell as Richard Hannay, Karen Dotrice as Alex, John Mills as Colonel Scudder, and a host of other well- known British actors in smaller parts.

title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
text: It is generally regarded as the closest to the novel, being set before the Great War.

title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
text: The early events and overall feel of the film bear much resemblance to Buchan's original story, albeit with a few changes such as the re-casting of Scudder as a more immediately sympathetic character and the introduction of a love interest.

title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
text: It also introduces a different meaning for the" thirty- nine steps", although unlike its filmed predecessors it returns to Buchan's original notion of being an actual staircase.

title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
text: It is known for the Big Ben sequence near the end, inspired by the film" My Learned Friend"( 1943), starring Will Hay, although this is its most fundamental deviation from Buchan's original story, which reaches its culmination in a coastal location in Kent.

title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
text: Powell later reprised the role in the ITV series" Hannay" which ran for 13 episodes from 1988 to 1989.

title: Jeff Celentano
text: Which won several film festivals as best comedy short.

title: Jeff Celentano
text: He also directed" Under the Hula MoonGunshy" starring Diane Lane, “ Breaking Point ” starring Tom Berenger and Busta Rhymes.

title: Jeff Celentano
text: and most recently the boxing saga" Glassjaw".

title: Jeff Celentano
text: Celentano is an acting teacher and is the Executive Director of Drama at The Performer's Academy in Lake Forest, California.

title: Jeff Celentano
text: Celentano was born and raised in Pemberton, New Jersey.

title: Mr. Right (2009 film)
text: Mr. Right is a 2009 British film directed by David Morris and Jacqui Morris.

title: Mr. Right (2009 film)
text: The jointly- made gay- themed film is the debut for both directors.

title: Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)
text: A Slayer, in the television series" Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and" Angel"( both created by Joss Whedon), is a young female bestowed with mystical powers that originate from the essence of a pure-demon, which gives her superhuman senses, strength, agility, resilience and speed in the fight against forces of darkness.

title: Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)
text: She occasionally receives prophetic dreams in the few hours that she sleeps.

title: Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)
text: The opening narration in the Buffy series states" Into every generation a slayer is born: one girl in all the world, a chosen one.

title: Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)
text: She alone will wield the strength and skill to fight the vampires, demons, and the forces of darkness; to stop the spread of their evil and the swell of their number.

title: Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)
text: She is the Slayer."

title: Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)
text: While, in the series, they are commonly referred to as" Vampire Slayers", even by Watchers and vampires themselves, the Slayer may operate as a defender against any and all supernatural threats.

title: Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)
text: The reputation of the Slayer is well- known and revered, even throughout other dimensions.

title: Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)
text: The notion of the Slayer has been compared to the equivalent of a Demonic" Boogey- Man", incredibly feared and considered by most to be essentially unconquerable.

title: Edinburgh Collegiate School
text: Edinburgh Collegiate School was located at 27/28 Charlotte Square, Edinburgh.

title: Edinburgh Collegiate School
text: The school was established in 1868.

title: Chisipite Junior School
text: Chisipite Junior School is an independent, preparatory, day school for girls in Harare, Zimbabwe.

title: Chisipite Junior School
text: The school was founded in 1929 by Maisie Jenkinson as a small farm school.

title: Chisipite Junior School
text: Chisipite Junior School is a member of the Association of Trust Schools( ATS) and the Head is a member of the Conference of Heads of Independent Schools in Zimbabwe( CHISZ).

title: Royal Preparatory School
text: Royal Preparatory School( also known as" Royal Primary School" or" Royal Junior School") was a preparatory school in Colombo, Ceylon( now Sri Lanka).

title: Royal Preparatory School
text: Its grounds and buildings now form the primary school of the Royal College Colombo.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: Whitehorse Manor Junior School is a junior school for pupils aged between seven and eleven years.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: The school is located in Thornton Heath.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: In April 2011 the school became part of the first Academy Trust in Croydon and the running of the school became part of the responsibility of the Pegasus Academy Trust, a public company limited by guarantee.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: The Executive Headteachers of The Pegasus Academy Trust are Jolyon Roberts and Lynne Sampson.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: The school caters for pupils from Year 3 to Year 6.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: The uniform of the school is a burgundy sweatshirt with the school logo, white shirt and grey trousers or skirt.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: The school is expanding the number of forms on entry from two to three.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: There are currently 450 pupils on roll with a maximum of 30 pupils in each of 15 classes.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: To cater for these extra children a major building project took place between April 2010 and April 2014 providing seven extra classrooms, new offices, extended hall and library.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: The scheme was designed by the architects Hayhurst and Co and won a RIBA London award in May 2014.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: In September 2014 the school opened an annexe about away known as Whitehorse Manor- Brigstock site which allows another 210 children to be educated by the school- the original site having reached capacity.

title: Whitehorse Manor Junior School
text: The current Head of School is Nina Achenbach BA( QTS), NPQH.

title: Bramcote School

title: Bramcote School
text: In 2012, the school merged with Scarborough College and is now known as Bramcote Junior School.

title: Flagg Grove School

title: Flagg Grove School
text: The school was established in the late 19th century and now operates as the Tina Turner Museum.

title: First school
text: See infant school, junior school, or primary school and primary education.

title: Joshi Seigakuin Junior & Senior High School
text: In 1905 the school was established.

title: Sabawoon Rehabilitation Centre
text: Sabawoon Rehabilitation Centre is a rehabilitation institute in Mingora, Swat, Pakistan.

title: Sabawoon Rehabilitation Centre
text: " Sabawoon" in Pashto means" Morning Light".

title: Sabawoon Rehabilitation Centre
text: The centre, run and established by Pakistan Army with the help of the Hum Pakistani Foundation( an NGO) and UNICEF, was inaugurated in 2009 by General Ashfaq Pervez Kayani.

title: Sabawoon Rehabilitation Centre
text: Initially 22 former militants were inducted into the institute in September 2009.

title: Sachigo Lake
text: Sachigo Lake is a lake in Unorganized Kenora District in Northwestern Ontario, Canada.

title: Sachigo Lake
text: It is on the Sachigo River and is part of the Hudson Bay drainage basin.

title: Sachigo Lake
text: The major inflows are the Sachigo River at the southwest and the Morrison River at the east.

title: Sachigo Lake
text: The major outflow is the Sachigo River at the north, which flows via the Severn River to Hudson Bay.

title: Sachigo Lake
text: The principal location of the Sachigo Lake First Nation is located on the northwest shore of the lake.

title: Green Lake (Ontario)
text: Green Lake is a lake located in Renfrew County, Ontario, Canada.

title: McEvoy Lake
text: McEvoy Lake is a lake located in Yukon, Canada.

title: Swan Lake (Manitoba)
text: Swan Lake is a lake located in the Canadian province of Manitoba.

title: Swan Lake (Manitoba)
text: The lake, and several other features in the area, are named after the trumpeter swans found in the region.

title: Rush Lake (Wisconsin)
text: Rush Lake is a lake located in Winnebago County, Wisconsin.

title: Little Sachigo Lake
text: Little Sachigo Lake is a lake in Unorganized Kenora District in Northwestern Ontario, Canada.

title: Little Sachigo Lake
text: It is on the Sachigo River and is part of the Hudson Bay drainage basin.

title: Little Sachigo Lake
text: The major inflow, from the south, and outflow, at the east, is the Sachigo River, which flows via the Severn River to Hudson Bay.

title: Little Sachigo Lake
text: The closest settlement is the principal location of the Sachigo Lake First Nation, about south and upstream on the Sachigo River.

title: Anderson Lake (Illinois)
text: Anderson Lake is a freshwater lake located in Fulton County, Illinois.

title: Holden Lake
text: Holden Lake is a lake of Ontario, Canada.

title: Rush Lake (Minnesota)
text: Rush Lake is a lake located in Rush Lake and Otto Townships in Otter Tail County, Minnesota.

title: Wanetta Lake
text: Wanetta Lake is a lake located on Vancouver Island west of Kennedy Lake and south of the Kennedy River

title: Princess Henriette of Belgium
text: Princess Henriette of Belgium, later Princess Henriette of Orléans, Duchess of Vendôme( 30 November 1870 – 28 March 1948), was the daughter of Prince Philippe, Count of Flanders, and Princess Marie of Hohenzollern- Sigmaringen.

title: Princess Henriette of Belgium
text: She was the younger twin sister of Princess Joséphine Marie of Belgium, who died at the age of six weeks in 1871.

title: Duchess Elisabeth Alexandrine of Württemberg
text: Duchess Elisabeth Alexandrine Constance of Württemberg( 27 February 1802 in Würzau, Courland Governorate – 5 December 1864, in Karlsruhe) was a daughter of Duke Louis of Württemberg and Princess Henriette of Nassau- Weilburg.

title: Princess Joséphine Marie of Belgium
text: Princess Joséphine Marie of Belgium( 30 November 1870 — 18 January 1871) was the daughter of Prince Philippe, Count of Flanders, and Princess Marie of Hohenzollern- Sigmaringen.

title: Princess Joséphine Marie of Belgium
text: She was the older twin to Princess Henriette of Belgium.

title: Princess Joséphine Marie of Belgium
text: In 1872 Joséphine Marie's mother gave birth to another daughter, who was named Joséphine in her memory.

title: Pauline Therese of Württemberg
text: Pauline of Württemberg (4 September 1800 – 10 March 1873) was a daughter of Duke Louis of Württemberg and Princess Henriette of Nassau-Weilburg.

title: Pauline Therese of Württemberg
text: She married her first cousin King William I of Württemberg and was his consort.

title: Henriette of France (1727–1752)
text: Anne "Henriette" of France(14 August 1727 – 10 February 1752) was a French princess, the twin of Louise Élisabeth of France, and the second child of King Louis XV of France and queen consort Marie Leszczyńska.

title: Marie Leszczyńska
text: Maria Karolina Zofia Felicja Leszczyńska (23 June 1703 – 24 June 1768), also known as Marie Leczinska , was a Polish princess and French queen consort.

title: Marie Leszczyńska
text: The daughter of King Stanisław Leszczyński—Stanislaus I of Poland (later Duke of Lorraine)–and Catherine Opalińska, she married King Louis XV of France and became queen consort of France.

title: Marie Leszczyńska
text: She served in that role for 42 years from 1725 until her death in 1768, the longest service of any queen of France, and was popular due to her generosity and piety.

title: Marie Leszczyńska
text: She was the grandmother of Louis XVI, Louis XVIII and Charles X of France.

title: Duke Alexander of Württemberg (1804–1885)
text: Duke Alexander Paul Ludwig Konstantin of Württemberg( 9 September 1804, Saint Petersburg – 4 July 1885 Tüffer) was the father of Francis, Duke of Teck and the grandfather of Mary of Teck, wife of George V of the United Kingdom.

title: Duke Alexander of Württemberg (1804–1885)
text: His father was Duke Louis of Württemberg, brother of King Frederick I of Württemberg and Empress Maria Feodorovna of Russia.

title: Duke Alexander of Württemberg (1804–1885)
text: His mother was Princess Henriette of Nassau- Weilburg, a great- granddaughter of George II of Great Britain through his eldest daughter Anne, Princess of Orange.

title: Duchess Maria Dorothea of Württemberg
text: Duchess Maria Dorothea of Württemberg( Maria Dorothea Luise Wilhelmine Caroline; 1 November 1797 in Carlsruhe( now Pokój), Silesia – 30 March 1855 in Pest, Hungary) was the daughter of Duke Louis of Württemberg( 1756 – 1817) and Princess Henriette of Nassau- Weilburg( 1780 – 1857).

title: Princess Henriette of Schönaich-Carolath
text: Princess Henriette of Schönaich- Carolath( 25 November 191816 March 1972) was the youngest daughter of Prince Johann George von Schönaich- Carolath and Princess Hermine Reuss of Greiz, who later became the second wife of Wilhelm II, German Emperor.

title: Princess Henriette of Liechtenstein
text: Princess Henriette of Liechtenstein( German:" Henriette Maria Norberta, Prinzessin von und zu Liechtenstein"; 6 June 1843 – 24 December 1931) was a Princess of Liechtenstein and member of the Princely House of Liechtenstein.

title: The Last Night (1936 film)
text: The Last Night is a 1936 Soviet drama film directed by Yuli Raizman.

title: Leave It to Me (1955 film)
text: Leave It to Me is a 1955 Czech comedy film directed by Martin Frič.

title: The Last Night of the Barbary Coast
text: The Last Night of the Barbary Coast( 1913) was an early example of the exploitation film, showing what was purported to be the last night of the Barbary Coast red-light section of San Francisco.

title: The Last Night of the Barbary Coast
text: In reality, the Barbary Coast was n't shut down until 1917.

title: The Last Night of the Barbary Coast
text: The film, directed by Hal Mohr and Sol Lesser, is now considered a lost film.

title: The Last Night of the Barbary Coast
text: Mohr, later an Academy Award winner, did the cinematography, and Lesser went on to become a Hollywood producer.

title: Leave It to Henry
text: Leave It to Henry is a 1949 American comedy film directed by Jean Yarbrough and written by D.D. Beauchamp.

title: Leave It to Henry
text: The film stars Raymond Walburn, Walter Catlett, Gary Gray, Mary Stuart, Barbara Brown and Houseley Stevenson.

title: Leave It to Henry
text: The film was released on June 12, 1949, by Monogram Pictures.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: Takhir Sabirov( December 21, 1929 – May 30, 2002) is a Tajik film director, actor, screenwriter, art director, and one of the most notable figures of the Tajik cinema.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: He is known as the" founding father" of the" One Thousand and One Nights" dynasty of the film industry due to his creation of the' Scheherazade' trilogy.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: He is also known by his formal name Takhir Mukhtorovich Sabirov.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: His mother" Mastona Sobir Zoda" was the daughter of Duke" Sobir- kaloni Tura-zoda" of Samarkand( now part of the Samarqand Province, Uzbekistan), from the Duchy of Greater Khorasan, known as" Tura- zoda", who were eminent members of Central Asia's Aristocracy.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: Takhir was the youngest of five children.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: He was married twice and has two sons and three daughters.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: He completed the Performing Arts discipline at the Tashkent State Art Institute of Theatrical Arts in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: In 1951, he then continued further by obtaining his Directorial discipline under faculty of Yuri Zavadsky at The Russian Academy of Theatre Arts( GITIS) in Moscow, Russia.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: His first film," Roh"( 1955)

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: ( Russian title:" Дорога") produced by Mosfilm initiated him into the film industry, but the role of" Yodgor" in" Dokhunda"( 1956) sparked his career and was followed by several successful roles.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: His directorial debut was in" Vaqti zangirii pisar rasid"( Russian title:" Sinu para jinitsa", 1959), which was the first comedy musical motion picture in the Cinema of Tajikistan.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: With his films he introduced the Tajik film industry onto international scenebasis with his nomination in International film festivals.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: His film" Margi Sudkhur"( Russian title:" Smert' Rostovshika", 1966) was nominated at the International Film Festival of Asia and Africa in 1968.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: His trilogy of" New Tales of ScheherazadeAnother Night of Scheherazade" and" The Last Night of Scheherazade" that were based on the Arabic folktale" One Thousand and One Nights" had made a great impact in the Cinema of Tajikistan by opening it to European audiences and borders.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: The Scheherazade trilogies were among one of the first Tajik film productions that achieved distribution beyond Russian( former USSR) borders, placing Tajik film on the map of International Film Festivals.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: Not only has he directed and co-written the Scheherazade trilogies, but also starred as King Shahryar( Sultan); which coincidentally is more true to his own lineage of royalty.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: He became a cultural icon gaining more acknowledgement and respect.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: Regardless of the obstacles he had faced in his lifetime, he never stopped filming.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: He is known in the Tajik film industry as one of the major film directors of his time.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: He broadened his entertainment field as he established entrepreneurial joint venture" Movarounnahr Joint Venture" as an Art Director.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: Although he was involved in many fields of the film industry, he always had time to instruct and inspire students and apprentices.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: In 1999, he was part of the judging committee in the 21st( XXI) Moscow International Film Festival.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: He became the first Tajik film director to be honored with the position of a film judge.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: In 2002, he was an honorary guest at the 55th( LV) Cannes Film Festival.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: Even in his seventy years of age he was involved in film production.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: However, on May 30, 2002 he died with his film" Khoja Kamoli Khujandi" still in production.

title: Takhir Sabirov
text: In 2003, a street," Takhir Sabirov Street" was named after his death for his contributions in the Cinema of Tajikistan( Tajikfilm, Tajik Film Studio).

title: Leave It to Me (1933 film)
text: Leave It to Me is a 1933 British comedy film directed by Monty Banks and starring Gene Gerrard, Olive Borden and Molly Lamont.

title: Leave It to Me (1933 film)
text: It was made at Elstree Studios.

title: Leave It to Me (1933 film)
text: The film's sets were designed by the art director David Rawnsley.

title: Leave It to Me (1933 film)
text: It is an adaptation of the play" Leave It to Psmith"( 1930) by Ian Hay and P.G. Wodehouse, which is based on Wodehouse's novel" Leave It to Psmith"( 1923).

title: Frank Bank
text: Frank Bank( April 12, 1942 – April 13, 2013) was an American actor, particularly known for his role as Clarence" Lumpy" Rutherford on the 1957 – 1963 situation comedy television series" Leave It to Beaver".

title: Frank Bank
text: Bank was cast in fifty episodes of" Leave It to Beaver" between January 24, 1958, until the series finale on May 30, 1963.

title: Frank Bank
text: Thereafter, he was cast as Clarence Rutherford in 101 episodes of the series sequel," The New Leave It to Beaver", which aired on cable television from 1985 to 1989.

title: Frank Bank
text: Beginning in 1973, Bank became a bond broker in his native Los Angeles.

title: Frank Bank
text: His autobiography," Call Me Lumpy: My Leave It To Beaver Days and Other Wild Hollywood Life," was published in 1997.

title: Frank Bank
text: Bank died of cancer on April 13, 2013, in Rancho Mirage, California, one day after his 71st birthday.

title: Frank Bank
text: He was survived by his third wife, Rebecca, four daughters, and five grandchildren.

title: Frank Bank
text: He is interred at Hillside Memorial Park Cemetery in Culver City, California.

title: Henry Moore (cricketer)
text: Henry Walter Moore( 1849 – 20 August 1916) was an English- born first- class cricketer who spent most of his life in New Zealand.

title: Jean Yarbrough
text: Jean Yarbrough (August 22, 1901 – August 2, 1975) was an American film director.

title: The Last Night of Scheherazade
text: The Last Night of Scheherazade is a 1987 Soviet- Syrian children's fantasy film directed by Takhir Sabirov based on" One Thousand and One Nights".

title: The Last Night of Scheherazade
text: It is the last film of the trilogy, started with the films" New Tales of Scheherazade" and" And another night of Scheherazade".

title: The Last Night of Scheherazade
text: The heroes of the film are the shoemaker Maruf and the daughter of the Caliph, Esmagül, who despite falling in love with a young man, nevertheless forces him to fight for his own happiness.

title: Dedi I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Dedi (or Dedo) (1004 – October 1075) was the Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark (also called Lower Lusatia) from 1046 and a claimant for the title of Margrave of Meissen from 1069.

title: Dedi I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: He was the second son of Dietrich II of Wettin and Matilda, daughter of Eckard I of Meissen.

title: Thietmar, Margrave of Meissen
text: Thietmar (II) (– 3 August 979) was Margrave of Meissen from about 976 until his death.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: Henry II( 1103 – 1123) was the Margrave of Meissen and the Saxon Ostmark( as" Lusizensis marchio": margrave of Lusatia) from his birth until his death.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: He was the posthumous son of Margrave Henry I and Gertrude of Brunswick, daughter of Egbert I of Meissen.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: He was by inheritance also Count of Eilenburg.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: He was the second Meissener margrave of the House of Wettin.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: He was initially under the regency of his great uncle Thimo.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: He died young and without children in 1123.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: His lands were inherited by his half- sister Richenza of Northeim.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: He left a widow, Adelaide, daughter of Lothair Udo III, Margrave of the Nordmark.

title: Henry II, Margrave of Meissen
text: The succession to the marches was disputed after his death.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Odo( or Hodo) I( also" Huodo" or" Huoto")( c. 930 – 13 March 993) was margrave in the Saxon Eastern March of the Holy Roman Empire from 965 until his death.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Odo was, if the onomastics are correct, a son( or maybe a nephew) of Christian( d. 950), a Saxon count in the Nordthüringgau and Schwabengau of Eastphalia.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Count Christian, probably a scion of the Billung dynasty, had married Hidda( d. 970), a sister of Gero, margrave of the vast" marca Geronis" in the lands settled by Polabian Slavs.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: From 945 he also ruled over the adjacent gau of Serimunt beyond the Saale river.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: In 965, Margrave Gero died and his great" marca Geronis" was divided into five smaller marches.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Count Thietmar, a known son of Hidda, and Odo inherited large parts of his march:

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Odo received the so- called" marca Orientalis" or Eastern March, stretching from the Gau Serimunt in the west up to the remotest outposts on the Bóbr river in the east, while Thietmar appeared as margrave of southern Meissen after 970.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Both are buried at Nienburg Abbey, a foundation of Thietmar and his brother Archbishop Gero of Cologne, which too provides evidence of their probable relationship.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: As a young man, Margrave Odo had shared the tutorship of Otto's son( later Otto II) with the boy's step- uncle William, Archbishop of Mainz.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Archbishop William taught literature and culture; Margrave Odo taught war and legal customs.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Odo spent the first years of his rule subduing the Slavic tribes settling in the eastern parts of the Saxon Ostmark.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: He held comital rights in the gau of Nizizi, comprising the lands between the Mulde, Elbe and Black Elster rivers, and appeared with the title" marchio"( margrave) only in 974, though he had held further marcher territories( officially as a county) since 965.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: In that same year( 974), Odo was made Count in the Saxon Nordthüringgau, still rivalling with Margrave Thietmar.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Odo is chiefly known for his quarrels with the Polish duke Mieszko I.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: The West Slavic Polans had established a state east of the Saxon marches and, aiming to advance into the Pomeranian lands north of the Warta river, had reached an agreement with late Margrave Gero and Emperor Otto I: Mieszko's ducal title was confirmed and the Polans paid a recurring tribute to the emperor, which was collected by Margrave Odo.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: The medieval chronicler Thietmar of Merseburg, apparently quite gladly, relates that Odo's reputation with Mieszko was such that the duke of Poland" would not have dared while wearing his fur coat to enter a house where he knew the margrave to be, or to remain seated when the margrave stood up."

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: When in 972 the Polans again marched for the Baltic trade centre of Wolin, they entered into open conflict with Odo.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: The margrave, intending to compel Mieszko to pay tribute for the Pomeranian territory between the Oder and Warta rivers, invaded that region.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Aged Emperor

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Otto, engaged in the marriage of his son

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Otto II with Princess Theophanu at far- off

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Rome, ordered them to cease until he himself could arbitrate their dispute.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: However, Odo attacked Mieszko's forces and was defeated on 24 June at the Battle of Cedynia.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: The belligerents reconciled at the Imperial Diet in Quedlinburg one year later.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: In 983, Odo took part in the attempts to suppress the Great Slav Rising of the Polabian Lutici tribes, but was not able to prevent the loss of the Saxon Northern March.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: He also failed to succeed Thietmar in the Margraviate of Meissen in 979.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Odo left a son, Siegfried( d. 1030), who became a monk at Nienburg, but left the monastery on his father's death to claim his inheritance.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: He did however not prevail against Thietmar's son Gero II, who became Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark in 993.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Siegfried again appeared as a count from 1015, when he claimed the Saxon Ostmark from Gero's son Thietmar IV and allied with Duke Mieszko II of Poland in the German- Polish War.

title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Thietmar IV prevailed with the support by Emperor Henry II, but lost the eastern parts of his march to Mieszko II in the 1018 Peace of Bautzen.

title: Dedi II, Margrave of Lusatia
text: Dedi( or Dedo) II( died 1069), called the Younger, was the Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark( also called Lower Lusatia) in 1069.

title: Gero II, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Gero II (c. 975 – 1 September 1015 at Krosno Odrzańskie) was the eldest son of Thietmar, Margrave of Meissen, and Schwanehilde (Suanhild), daughter of Herman, Duke of Saxony.

title: Gero II, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: He was therefore probably a grandson of Hidda and Christian of Thuringia and named for his great uncle Gero the Great.

title: Gero II, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: He succeeded his probable uncle, Hodo, as Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark including Mark Lausitz (Lusatia) in 993 upon the death of margrave of Lusatia Hodo or Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark.

title: Gero II, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
text: Gero was created Count of Hassegau in 992, just a year before becoming margrave.

title: Kabani Nadi Chuvannappol

title: When the Mountains Tremble
text: When The Mountains Tremble is a 1983 documentary film produced by Skylight Pictures about the war between the Guatemalan Military and the Mayan Indigenous population of Guatemala.

title: When the Mountains Tremble

title: Owen Lloyd George, 3rd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: Owen Lloyd George, 3rd Earl Lloyd- George of Dwyfor, DL( 28 April 1924 – 29 July 2010) was a British Peer.

title: Owen Lloyd George, 3rd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: He sat as a crossbencher in the House of Lords.

title: David Lloyd George
text: David Lloyd George, 1st Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor, (17 January 1863 – 26 March 1945) was a British statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom between 1916 and 1922.

title: David Lloyd George
text: He was the final Liberal to hold the post.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Lloyd George was born in Manchester to Welsh parents.

title: David Lloyd George
text: His father—a schoolmaster—died in 1864 and he was raised in Wales by his mother and her shoemaker brother, whose Liberal politics and Baptist faith strongly influenced Lloyd George; the same uncle helped the boy embark on a career as a solicitor after leaving school.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Lloyd George became active in local politics, gaining a reputation as an orator and a proponent of a Welsh blend of radical Liberalism which championed nonconformism and the disestablishment of the Anglican church in Wales, equality for labourers and tenant farmers, and reform of landownership.

title: David Lloyd George
text: In 1890, he narrowly won a by-election to become the Member of Parliament for Caernarvon Boroughs, in which seat he remained for fifty-five years.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Lloyd George served in Henry Campbell-Bannerman's cabinet from 1905.

title: David Lloyd George
text: After H. H. Asquith succeeded to the premiership in 1908, Lloyd George replaced him as Chancellor of the Exchequer.

title: David Lloyd George
text: To fund extensive welfare reforms, he proposed taxes on land ownership and high incomes in the "People's Budget" (1909), which the Conservative-dominated House of Lords rejected.

title: David Lloyd George
text: The resulting constitutional crisis was only resolved after two elections in 1910 and the passage of the Parliament Act 1911.

title: David Lloyd George
text: His budget was then enacted alongside the National Insurance Act 1911 which helped to establish the modern welfare state.

title: David Lloyd George
text: In 1913, he was embroiled in the Marconi scandal but he remained in office and struggled to impose Irish Home Rule until the outbreak of the First World War in 1914 suspended its implementation.

title: David Lloyd George
text: As wartime Chancellor, Lloyd George strengthened the country's finances and forged agreements with trade unions to maintain production.

title: David Lloyd George
text: In 1915, Asquith formed a Liberal-led wartime coalition with the Conservatives and Labour.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Lloyd George became Minister of Munitions and rapidly expanded production.

title: David Lloyd George
text: In 1916, he was appointed Secretary of State for War but was frustrated by his limited power and clashes with the military establishment over strategy.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Amid stalemate on the Western Front, confidence in Asquith's leadership waned.

title: David Lloyd George
text: He was forced to resign in December 1916; Lloyd George succeeded him as Prime Minister, supported by the Conservatives and some Liberals.

title: David Lloyd George
text: He centralised authority through a smaller war cabinet, a new Cabinet Office and his "Garden Suburb" of advisers.

title: David Lloyd George
text: To combat food shortages he implemented the convoy system, established rationing, and stimulated farming.

title: David Lloyd George
text: After supporting the disastrous French Nivelle Offensive in 1917, he had to reluctantly approve Field Marshal Haig's plans for the Battle of Passchendaele which resulted in huge casualities with little strategic benefit.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Against the views of his commanders, he was finally able to see the Allies brought under one command in March 1918.

title: David Lloyd George
text: The war effort turned to their favour that August and was won in November.

title: David Lloyd George
text: In the aftermath, he and the Conservatives maintained their coalition with popular support following the December 1918 "Coupon" election.

title: David Lloyd George
text: His government had extended the franchise to all men and some women earlier in the year.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Lloyd George was a major player in Paris Peace Conference of 1919 but the situation in Ireland worsened that year, erupting into the Irish War of Independence which lasted until Lloyd George negotiated independence for the Irish Free State in 1921.

title: David Lloyd George
text: At home he initiated reforms to education and housing but trade union militancy entered record levels, the economy became depressed in 1920 and unemployment rose; spending cuts followed (1921–22) and he was embroiled in a scandal over the sale of honours and the Chanak Crisis in 1922.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Bonar Law won backbench support for the Conservatives to contend the next election alone.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Lloyd George resigned; with his party split between his and Asquith's supporters, his faction won less than 60 seats in the 1922 election.

title: David Lloyd George
text: The next year the pair reunited to oppose Stanley Baldwin's tariff proposal which he put to the country.

title: David Lloyd George
text: The Liberals made gains in 1923 but remained third after the Conservatives and Labour, propping up a Labour minority government; they never regained their status as second party and, when the Labour government fell, went down to just over 40 seats in 1924 under Asquith.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Lloyd George led the Liberals from 1926 to 1931, putting forward innovative proposals for public works; this failed to convert into seats in 1929 and from 1931 he was a marginalised and mistrusted figure heading a small rump of breakaway Liberals opposed to the National Government.

title: David Lloyd George
text: He declined an offer to serve in Winston Churchill's War Cabinet in 1940 and was raised to the peerage in 1945, shortly before his death.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Lloyd George has often been ranked highly among modern British prime ministers, but his legacy remains complicated and controversial.

title: David Lloyd George
text: Scholars have praised his welfare reforms and his efforts to mobilise and lead Britain to victory during the First World War, but he has also been criticised for adopting a "presidential" style of leadership, for distrusting his own commanders during the war, and for his strategic failures and involvement in various scandals.

title: David Lloyd George
text: His legacies over Ireland and the Treaty of Versailles are also controversial.

title: David Lloyd George
text: In the post-war period, he arguably alienated many of the workers he had earlier championed, helping to swell Labour's popular support at the Liberals' expense (not helped by his conflicts with Asquithian Liberals after 1916).

title: A. J. Sylvester
text: Albert James Sylvester( 24 November 1889 – 27 October 1989) served as Principal Private Secretary to British statesman David Lloyd George from 1923 until Lloyd George's death in March 1945.

title: A. J. Sylvester
text: A native of Harlaston, Staffordshire, Sylvester served as private secretary to the Secretary to the Committee of Imperial Defence, 1914 – 1921, to the Secretary of the War Cabinet and the Cabinet, 1916 – 1921, to the Secretary of the Imperial War Cabinet, 1917, to the British Secretary of the Paris Peace Conference, 1919, and to three successive Prime Ministers, 1921- 3: Lloyd George, Bonar Law and Stanley Baldwin.

title: A. J. Sylvester
text: He ran Lloyd George's private office in London.

title: A. J. Sylvester
text: After Lloyd George's death, A. J. Sylvester earned his living as a member of Lord Beaverbrook's staff from 1945 until 1948, and spent a further year as unpaid assistant to the Liberal Party leader, Clement Davies.

title: A. J. Sylvester
text: In 1947, he published" The Real Lloyd George", based on his diaries.

title: A. J. Sylvester
text: In 1949, he retired from political life, and moved to a farm at Corsham, Wiltshire, England, where he served as JP.

title: A. J. Sylvester
text: His ambition to publish a full- scale autobiography, upon which he was actively engaged in extreme old age, never came to fruition.

title: A. J. Sylvester
text: His papers provide an insight into the life of Lloyd George after his fall from power in 1922.

title: Gwilym Lloyd George
text: Gwilym Lloyd George, 1st Viscount Tenby, (4 December 1894 – 14 February 1967) was a British politician and cabinet minister.

title: Gwilym Lloyd George
text: The younger son of Prime Minister David Lloyd George, he served as Home Secretary from 1954 to 1957.

title: William Lloyd George, 3rd Viscount Tenby
text: William Lloyd George, 3rd Viscount Tenby, JP( born 7 November 1927) is a British peer and former Army officer.

title: William Lloyd George, 3rd Viscount Tenby
text: Tenby was elected one of the initial ninety hereditary peers to remain in the House of Lords after the passing of the House of Lords Act 1999 until his retirement in 2015.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor (15 February 1889 – 1 May 1968) was a British soldier and peer in the peerage of the United Kingdom, a member of the House of Lords from 1945 until his death.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: The son of the Liberal prime minister David Lloyd George by his first wife, Margaret Owen, Lloyd George was educated at Portmadoc School and Christ's College, Cambridge, graduating BA in 1910.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: During the First World War he was commissioned into the Royal Engineers and rose to the rank of Major.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: He became an associate member of the Institution of Civil Engineers and served in the British Army again during the Second World War.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: On 7 April 1917 Lloyd George married Roberta McAlpine (1898–1966), a daughter of Sir Robert McAlpine, 1st Baronet.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: They had two children, Valerie Davidia (1918–2000) and Owen (1924–2010), before being divorced in 1933.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: In 1935 Lloyd George married secondly Winifred Emily Peedle, a daughter of Thomas W. Peedle.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: Valerie became the wife of the academic and broadcasting executive, Sir Goronwy Daniel.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: On 1 January 1945 his father was created Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor, and he gained the courtesy title of Viscount Gwynedd.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: Less than three months later, on 26 March 1945, his father died of cancer and he inherited his peerage, unusually becoming the first member of the family to sit in the House of Lords, as David Lloyd George had been too ill to do so.

title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
text: He wrote a biography of his mother, "Dame Margaret", and of his father, "Lloyd George".

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Frances Lloyd George, Countess Lloyd- George of Dwyfor,( 7 October 1888 – 5 December 1972) was the mistress, personal secretary, confidante and second wife of British Prime Minister David Lloyd George.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Frances Louise Stevenson was born in London.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: She was the daughter of a Lowland Scottish father and a mother of mixed French and Italian extraction.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: She was educated at Clapham High School, where in the fifth form she had made friends with Mair, Lloyd George's oldest daughter, and then at Royal Holloway College where she studied Classics.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: In July 1911, Lloyd George, then Chancellor of the Exchequer, hired Stevenson as a governess for his youngest daughter Megan.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Lloyd George and Stevenson were soon attracted to each other.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Although Stevenson, who wanted a conventional marriage and many children, hesitated about becoming the mistress of a married man, she agreed to become Lloyd George's personal secretary on his terms, which included a sexual relationship, in 1913.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: She was created a Commander of the Order of the British Empire in the 1918 New Year Honours and accompanied Lloyd George to the Paris Peace Conference of 1919.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: The delegates were under the impression she was still just his secretary.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Stevenson chose the location and supervised the construction of Lloyd George's house Bron- y- de in Churt, Surrey.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: She also arranged and collated Lloyd George's extensive archive of personal and political papers so that he could write his" War Memoirs".

title: Frances Stevenson
text: After having had two abortions, Stevenson gave birth to a daughter, Jennifer, in 1929.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Stevenson had been having an affair with Thomas Tweed, a novelist and Liberal Party official.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Stevenson encouraged Lloyd George to believe the child was his, but it is more likely that her father was Tweed.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Two years after Lloyd George's wife Margaret died, Stevenson married Lloyd George on 23 October 1943 despite the disapproval of Lloyd George's children from his first marriage.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Less than 18 months later, Lloyd George died on 26 March 1945.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: As Dowager Countess Lloyd- George of Dwyfor, she lived at Churt for the rest of her life, devoting her time to her family, charitable activities, perpetuating the memory of Lloyd George and writing.

title: Frances Stevenson
text: Her memoir" The Years That Are Past" was published in 1967, and her diary of her life with Lloyd George was published in 1971.

text: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus, Lord of Liddesdale and Jedburgh Forest (1426–1446) was a Scottish nobleman.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: He was the son of William Douglas, 2nd Earl of Angus and Margaret Hay of Yester.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: Angus succeeded at the age of eleven years and was soon involved in strife with his Black Douglas cousins.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: He was forfeited of his estates by James II in 1445, under the influence of his near cousin William Douglas, 8th Earl of Douglas.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: The Earl of Douglas was trying to consolidate the power which he had gained through the murder of his cousins at the "Black Dinner" at Edinburgh Castle, sanctioned by the king and his own father James the Gross, 7th Earl of Douglas.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: It has been suggested that the feud between the Black and Red Lines of the House of Douglas was encouraged by Bishop Kennedy of St. Andrews as a method of curtailing the power of unruly magnates, and ensuring continued Stewart reign.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: Kennedy was a first cousin through Angus' grandmother, Princess Mary of Scotland, a daughter of King Robert III.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: During his forfeiture, Angus was surprised at the reluctance of his tenantry to pay their Feus, he made a point of collecting them punctually in person.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: Angus died in 1446.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: He was betrothed briefly to Princess Joan, third daughter of King James I

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus
text: , she was twelve years old when he died and was with her sister the Dauphine of France.

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus

title: James Douglas, 3rd Earl of Angus

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Boris Yefimovich Nemtsov (9 October 195927 February 2015) was a Russian physicist and liberal politician.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Nemtsov was one of the most important figures in the introduction of capitalism into the Russian post-Soviet economy.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: He had a successful political career in the 1990s under President Boris Yeltsin.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: From 2000 until his death, he was an outspoken critic of Vladimir Putin.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Nemtsov was assassinated on 27 February 2015, beside his Ukrainian partner Anna Duritskaya, on a bridge near the Kremlin in Moscow, with four shots fired from the back.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: In the weeks before his death, Nemtsov expressed fear that Putin would have him killed.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: In late June 2017, five Chechen men were found guilty by a jury in a Moscow court for agreeing to kill Nemtsov in exchange for 15 million rubles (US$253,000); neither the identity nor whereabouts of the person who hired them is known.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Nemtsov criticized Putin's government as an increasingly authoritarian, undemocratic regime, highlighting widespread embezzlement and profiteering ahead of the Sochi Olympics, and Russian political interference and military involvement in Ukraine.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: After 2008, Nemtsov published in-depth reports detailing the corruption under Putin, which he connected directly with the President.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: As part of the same political struggle, Nemtsov was an active organizer of and participant in Dissenters' Marches, Strategy-31 civil actions and rallies "For Fair Elections".

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: At the time of the assassination, Nemtsov was in Moscow helping to organize a rally against the Russian military intervention in Ukraine and the Russian financial crisis.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: At the same time, Nemtsov was working on a report demonstrating that Russian troops were fighting alongside pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine, which the Kremlin had been denying, and was unpopular externally but also in Russia.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Nemtsov was the first governor of the Nizhny Novgorod Oblast (1991–97).

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Later he worked in the government of Russia as Minister of Fuel and Energy (1997),

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Vice Premier of Russia and Security Council member from 1997 to 1998.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: In 1998, he founded the Young Russia movement.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: In 1998, he co-founded the coalition group Right Cause and in 1999, he co-formed Union of Right Forces, an electoral bloc and subsequently a political party.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Nemtsov was also a member of the Congress of People's Deputies (1990), Federation Council (1993–97) and State Duma (1999–2003).

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: He also served as Vice Speaker of the State Duma and the leader of parliamentary group Union of Right Forces.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: After a 2008 split in the Union of Right Forces, he co-founded Solidarnost.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: In 2010, he co-formed the coalition "For Russia without Lawlessness and Corruption", which was refused registration as a party.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Beginning in 2012, Nemtsov was co-chair of the Republican Party of Russia – People's Freedom Party (RPR-PARNAS), a registered political party.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: At the time of his death, Nemtsov was one of the leaders of the Solidarnost ("Solidarity")

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: opposition movement, an elected member of the regional parliament of Yaroslavl Oblast, and co-chair of the RPR-PARNAS, which is a member of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, a Pan-European political party.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: After Nemtsov's murder, Serge Schmemann of "The New York Times" paid tribute to him in an article headlined "A Reformer Who Never Backed Down."

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Schmemann wrote: "Tall, handsome, witty and irreverent, Mr. Nemtsov was one of the brilliant young men who burst onto the Russian stage at that exciting moment when Communist rule collapsed and a new era seemed imminent.

title: Boris Nemtsov
text: Julia Ioffe of "The New York Times" described Nemtsov after his death as "a powerful, vigorous critic of Vladimir Putin", who was "a deeply intelligent, witty, kind and ubiquitous man" who "seemed to genuinely be everyone's friend".

title: Eystein Glumra
text: Eystein Glumra(" Eystein the Noisy" or" Eystein the Clatterer"; Modern Norwegian" Øystein Glumra") also known as Eystein Ivarsson, was reputedly a petty king on the west coast of Norway, during the 9th Century.

title: Eystein Glumra
text: The" Heimskringla" saga states that Eystein Glumra was the father of Rognvald Eysteinsson and Sigurd Eysteinsson:" The first earl in the Orkney Islands was called Sigurd, who was a son of Eystein Glumra, and brother of Ragnvald earl of More.

title: Eystein Glumra
text: After Sigurd, his son Guthorm was earl for one year.

title: Eystein Glumra
text: After him Torf- Einar, a son of Ragnvald, took the earldom, and was long earl, and was a man of great power".

title: Eystein Glumra
text: According to the" Orkneyinga Saga", Eystein Glumra was the son of Ivar the jarl of Uplanders and grandson of Halfdan the Old.

title: Eystein Glumra
text: " Orkneyinga Saga" also named Eystein Glumra as the father of Rognvald Eysteinsson:" Heiti, Gorr ’s son, was father of Sveiði the sea-king, the father of Halfdan the old, the father of Ivar the Uplanders ’ earl, the father of Eystein the noisy, the father of earl Rognvald the mighty and wise in council".

title: 2020 Korn Ferry Tour
